td.p: On March 12th, Governor Gavin Newsom issued an executive order in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. One of the directives of the executive order was to suspend the Brown Act governing public meetings in order to allow local governing boards "to hold via meetings teleconference and to make meetings accessible electronically.” Accordingly, the Board will meet via a teleconference. The public will be able view the meeting via a streaming feed. Access to that feed will be provided prior to the meeting. In keeping with local Public Health directions, there will not be a physical, in-person meeting on April 16th.

div.p: Dear Shoreline Families;
I’d like to share some information with all of you, as well as to send you some links to important information.

First of all, I want to thank you all for all that you are doing to support our students and our communities. This is such a difficult time with so much uncertainty, I am grateful for everyone’s flexibility, and intention to do what it takes to make it through these challenges.

The Shoreline District Distance Learning Plan can be read at this link. Our teachers and administrators have worked hard to develop this plan, and to make sure that all of our students have access to learning while classroom instruction is suspended. We are working with many community partners to identify ways to provide digital access and improved connectivity to our students. In the meantime, as you can read in the plan, we will continue to work hard to keep instructing our students.

SUSD has been partnering with the SF Marin Food Bank and the Marin County Department of Health and Human Services to distribute groceries along with our school meals to our school families and community. School meals are delivered on Mondays, and Food Bank groceries are delivered on Fridays. They are also available for pick up at West Marin School, Tomales Elementary School and Bodega Bay School. If you, or someone you know would like to be included in these deliveries or pick-ups, please call your child’s school office.

The 2020 US Census is in full swing. If you received your post card with your log-in information, please be sure to go online and complete the form. If you haven’t received your post card, you can go to this link, and enter in your information. The information that is collected in the census is confidential, and won’t be shared with any other government agency. We need to make sure that we are all counted, because the numbers from the Census help determine everything from how much of our tax dollars come back to our community to how many representatives we have in Washington DC. It’s essential that each and every one of us is counted!
Again, thanks for all that you are doing to support our students. Together, we will get through this!

div.p: On April 7th, the Marin County Office of Public Health and the Marin County Office of Education issued a press release, extending the suspension of classroom instruction through the end of the school year, assuming that the “shelter-in-place” order is not lifted before then.

I imagine that your reaction is much like mine. I am frustrated and saddened that our school year has taken such a strange and sudden turn. This calls upon all of us to redouble our efforts to ensure that your children receive the best instruction that we can provide, given the current state of affairs.

We have issued a Shoreline Distance Learning Plan to all staff and to the Board of Trustees. A parents’ version of the plan will be forthcoming, later this week. We are working with other districts in Marin County to develop a revised grading policy, especially for high school students, in light of this health crisis and changes to the University of California and California State University admissions policies.

The District has also been working with the County of Marin, as well as with other non-profit and private groups, to bring WIFI access to all of our families. I hope to have updates for all of you on that effort later this week.

We are continuing to work to support families who need assistance with food while the shelter-in-place order is in effect. We will continue to distribute school meals to those who need them each Monday, following the spring break. We are also creating a partnership with the San Francisco Marin Food Bank to provide food to our families and community. We will have more information on that effort later this week, as well.
Thank you for your understanding, and for all that you are doing to keep your families and your communities safe and healthy during this difficult time.
Sincerely,
Bob Raines

Earlier today, March 25th, the Marin Office of Public Health, in collaboration with the Public Health Offices of San Francisco, Alameda, Contra Costa, San Mateo and Santa Clara Counties, extended the suspension of classroom instruction for all students through May 1, 2020, in order to slow the spread of novel coronavirus (COVID-19). In compliance with that order, all Shoreline Unified School District schools will remain closed for student attendance through May 1st.

At the present time, our school and district offices will be open to the public only from 9:00 to 12:00 daily. Please contact your child’s school office if you have business that you must conduct in person, and cannot come in during those limited hours.

While schools remain closed for student attendance, our principals, teachers, secretaries, paraeducators, cooks, custodians and bus drivers will continue to provide services for our students. We will continue to deliver lunches to all eligible students, as well as to others who have requested to be included (if you would like your child to be included, please contact your child’s school office). Our teachers and instructional staff will be working to expand our distance learning offerings. In the coming days, you will receive more information from your school sites about how your children will receive remote instruction.
Thank you all for your understanding and for all that you are doing to support our students. I hope that you and all you hold dear stay well and safe during these difficult times.
Thank you.
I’d like to share a couple of quick notes with you all.

First of all, in an effort to maintain services to all of our families, while helping everyone stay safe, we are restricting public office hours at our school sites and the District Office to 9:00 to Noon, each day. Staff will be at all locations for outside of those hours, in order to continue providing all of our essential services, but the offices will be closed to the public outside of those hours. If you need to come to school or the District Office in person, and cannot manage to come during that time, please call the office in question and ask about arranging an alternate time.

The County Department of Public Health issued an order on Sunday, closing all public parks and playgrounds. In keeping with this order, we are closing our playgrounds, as well. As Public Health asks us to increase our efforts to stem the spread of the novel coronavirus, we will be passing along their notifications. Public Health Officer Dr. Matt Willis has instructed local law enforcement to enforce the Public Health Order at their discretion. Violation of the Public Health Order is a misdemeanor. It is punishable by fine, imprisonment, or both. The applicable section is California Health and Safety Code 120295. The San Rafael Police Department, at least, is interpreting the order to mean that groups of people in excess of one would be in violation. Please, do what you all can to stem the spread of the virus.
Thank you for understanding, and for taking good care of your families and our community.
Bob Raines

Yesterday, on March 19, 2020, Governor Newsom issued a shelter-in-place order for the entire state of California. In fact, that does little to change our situation in Marin County. The Governor’s proclamation continues to include schools among the essential services that will continue to operate. He also echoed Marin County’s direction to remain home except for certain essential activities, to maintain social distancing, and to practice heightened hygienic measures.

As a consequence of this order, in a conversation with Marin County’s superintendents, Dr. Matt Willis stated that playground use was no longer recommended. He encouraged us to reinforce with the families of our students that everyone, including our youngest children, must join our effort to slow the spread of the novel coronavirus. We understand that this is particularly difficult for parents, especially when children are increasingly impatient with the relative isolation of this modified “shelter-in-place.” In particular, when we are outdoors, walking or playing, we should be vigilant and continue to practice social distancing and our other safety measures.

We want you to know that our teachers and other staff will continue to provide our students with work and support while classroom instruction is suspended, and we are investigating ways to expand this support. Our school offices are open, on limited schedules, for your phone calls and emails. We will continue to provide school meals to eligible families, though we are making one delivery a week, with a whole week’s worth of lunch and breakfasts at a time. If you would like more information about our school meals, please call your child’s school office.

This is a very difficult time for us all, to be sure. In addition to following social distancing and enhanced hygiene practices, please take time to care for yourselves, as well. Hikes, music, and reading are all beneficial, emotionally as well as physically and intellectually.
We know that we will get through this. And we will get through it all together.
Thank you!
Bob Raines

Some parents have emailed me, citing their concerns about playdates for children during the “shelter in place,” period. Knowing that information is changing rapidly, I reached out to authorities and experts for more guidance.

First of all, all of the folks that I spoke with were clear; play dates for children are neither prohibited nor recommended. As with many aspects of the shelter in place order, parents are encouraged to make thoughtful and careful choices as they decide what is best for their children, their families and their community.

When a parent is considering whether or not to have their child get together with a very small group of their friends (2-4 children), there are a number of important limitations they should have in mind;

ul.li: Many children may not be able to maintain appropriate social distancing with their peers. It is against the nature of many children, both young ones and older, to stay six feet or more from their friends. Anytime anyone gathers, six feet of social distancing is the minimum we should maintain.

Playing outdoors is recommended, not only for the fresh air and open space, but also to avoid interacting with a variety of surfaces where the novel coronavirus may be. This includes, obviously, playgrounds, picnic tables, play equipment (such as balls) and another other outdoor structures where children would like to play or items they would play with.

Being thoughtful of the possibility of community contagion, one should not only avoid bringing children into the presence of individuals at risk, but also bringing them into the presence of others who may be caring for those individuals, or the children of those caring for vulnerable people.

div.p: The authorities and experts who I consulted stated that, ultimately, this is a parent’s decision, just as individuals decide when and how often to go to the grocery store or to conduct other personal business, and how they will protect themselves, their family and community when they do. They suggested that, as an alternative to physical play dates, that families who are fortunate to have the means may chose, instead, to arrange virtual play dates for their children. Above all, they all stressed, each parent should follow their own conscience, and respect the needs and desires of other families.

I will continue to seek the guidance of others, and pass that along to all of you as soon as I have new information. Additional guidance is always available on the Marin County Human Services COVID-19 webpage. Thanks for taking such good care of your children, your families, and our communities.

Algunos padres me han enviado correos electrónicos, citando sus preocupaciones sobre las fechas de juego para los niños durante el período de "refugio en el lugar". Sabiendo que la información está cambiando rápidamente, contacté a las autoridades y expertos para obtener más orientación.

En primer lugar, todas las personas con las que hablé fueron claras; Las fechas de juego para niños no están prohibidas ni recomendadas. Al igual que con muchos aspectos del refugio en el lugar orden, se alienta a los padres a tomar decisiones reflexivas y cuidadosas al decidir qué es lo mejor para sus hijos, sus familias y su comunidad.
Cuando un padre está considerando si su hijo debe reunirse o no con un grupo muy pequeño de amigos (2-4 hijos), hay una serie de limitaciones importantes que deben tener en cuenta;

• Es posible que muchos niños no puedan mantener un distanciamiento social adecuado con sus compañeros. Está en contra de la naturaleza de muchos niños, tanto jóvenes como mayores, mantenerse a seis pies o más de sus amigos. Cada vez que alguien se reúne, seis pies de distancia social es lo mínimo que debemos mantener.

• Se recomienda jugar al aire libre, no solo por el aire fresco y el espacio abierto, sino también para evitar interactuar con una variedad de superficies donde puede estar el nuevo coronavirus. Esto incluye, obviamente, parques infantiles, mesas de picnic, equipos de juego (como pelotas) y otras estructuras al aire libre donde a los niños les gustaría jugar o artículos con los que jugarían.

• Teniendo en cuenta la posibilidad de contagio comunitario, uno no solo debe evitar acercar a los niños a la presencia de personas en riesgo, sino también acercarlos a la presencia de otras personas que puedan estar cuidando a esas personas, o los niños de quienes cuidan a personas vulnerables personas.

Las autoridades y expertos a quienes consulté declararon que, en última instancia, esta es una decisión de los padres, así como las personas deciden cuándo y con qué frecuencia ir al supermercado o realizar otros negocios personales, y cómo se protegerán a sí mismos, a su familia y a la comunidad. cuando lo hacen Sugirieron que, como alternativa a las fechas de juego físico, las familias que tienen la suerte de tener los medios pueden optar, en cambio, por organizar fechas de juego virtuales para sus hijos. Sobre todo, todos destacaron, cada padre debe seguir su propia conciencia y respetar las necesidades y deseos de otras familias.

Continuaré buscando la guía de los demás, y la transmitiré a todos ustedes tan pronto como tenga nueva información. Siempre hay orientación adicional disponible en la página web COVID-19 de Servicios Humanos del Condado de Marin. Gracias por cuidar tan bien a sus hijos, sus familias y nuestras comunidades.
Thank you/Gracias,
Bob Raines
Dear Shoreline Families,

On March 16th, Dr. Matt Willis, the Marin County Public Health Officer, issued a proclamation calling on all Marin County residents who are not providing essential services to restrict their activities to only essential functions (purchasing food, seeing their doctor, etc.), until April 7th.

p.strong: As a result, all classroom instruction at our Shoreline Schools will be suspended, beginning Monday, March 16th until, at least, April 7th. All students are to remain home until we are notified that the classroom suspension is lifted.

div.p: All students will receive appropriate classroom assignments from their teachers, that can be completed during the time they are away from school. All students who receive meals through the Federal School Lunch Program will continue to receive those meals, which will be delivered by our cafeteria and transportation staff.

I want to stress that, at the present time, there are no known cases of COVID-19 in any of our schools. Our schools will remain open while classroom instruction is suspended. All of our hardworking district staff will be working during this time.

We will continue to update our families as we know more about this situation. Of course, we continue to stress that everyone follow some basic practices to ensure that we minimize the chance to spread any viruses, corona or otherwise:

ul.li: Cover all coughs and sneezes with the crook of the elbow or a tissue.
Wash hands for 20 seconds (two times through “Happy Birthday” or “Somewhere Over the Rainbow,” or any number of other songs at this link).
Isolate yourself if you have any flu-like symptoms (especially a fever) until you are fever-free (without medication) for 24 hours.

div.p: Thank you for your understanding. We realize that this is a difficult time for everyone. As we learn more, we will be in touch to keep you all informed.
Thank you
Superintendent
